The Unearthed Spoils Digital Magazine is a Dungeons and Dragons 5th Edition compatible supplement designed as a resource for game masters to use in their adventures. This product is compliant with the Open Game License (OGL) located on the last page of this product.

data.name: What's Inside
entries: {@b ARCHETYPE: CLERIC REPOSE DOMAIN}  Clerics of Repose deal with death and the lawful passing from one world to the next. These undertakers of the realm roam the land seeking out abominations and those who deal in souls.

{@b DEAD GODS AND UNDEAD MONSTERS}  More than a dozen new NPCs to add to your campaign, from a piece of a dead god and its spawn to a new race of salamander folk, these monsters are guaranteed to excite any adventurer.
{@b MAGICAL SPELLS}  Six balanced tier 1 spells to add depth to your players' game.
{@b ENCHANTED ITEMS}  Eleven new magic items, including the fruit of a dead god, a weapon that can increase in power with its owner and a new potion that just might come in handy.

{@b ADVENTURE! THE HARRIED HARVESTER}  An exciting adventure for level 6 players that can be dropped into any campaign that includes a forested area. Four full color maps to keep your players engaged, not that they will be needed as their characters deal with challenges that will keep them focused on their mission the entire time!

entries.name: Stronach
entries: When a piece of a dead god finds its way to this plane, it mindlessly changes the world around it.

entries.name: On The Cover
entries: Bob Greyvenstein depicts a cleric of repose as it keeps a watchful eye on its lawful domain.
Child, Do not fear the Death Priest. He is not here for you. He will perform his business and pass on to the next village soon.
Mind you behave, however, else you may see the skulls upon his robes up close!

entries.name: Repose Domain
entries: These lawful undertakers of the realm are not particularly benevolent. Clerics of Repose concern themselves with the matters of passing and ushering the spirit from the mortal world to the next. They abhor undead or anything that interferes with the natural course of the spirit in life and in death. Although children and the unwashed often fear these armed clergy, in their ubiquitous black and charcoal gray robes with symbols of death adorning them, the sage and experienced know that they bear no malice towards the average person. Only necromancers and those who deal in souls, such as devils and fiends need to fear their divine wrath.

They serve deities of the dead and as their service grows, they are granted powers that those who play with souls and the undead fear. Many of their orders produce special potions that do not heal but work as a prophylactic against death.

Clerics of Repose can raise the dead themselves but only do so to restore a lawful life to an unjust death, and always for a price. They are the undertakers of the realm and perform rites of passing on the battlefield and on deathbeds alike. The donations they receive for such services, and their potions, go towards maintaining their gothic temples where acolytes are trained in the esoteric divine domain of repose.

entries.name: Ken Judgment
entries: Starting when you choose this domain at 1st level, you become proficient with the Insight and Perception skills.

entries.name: Not Today
entries: At 1st level, you gain the ability to stabilize the dying by merely touching them. You learn the spare the dying cantrip if you do not know it already and can cast it as a bonus action.

entries.name: Channel Divinity: Seek Undead
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to see the unliving in your midst. As an action, you present your holy symbol and invoke the power of the Plane of Death.

Every undead creature within 60 feet that is within your line of sight is revealed to you in an outline of golden shimmering waves. Additionally, your power will reveal undead creatures on the Ethereal Plane by revealing any creature on the Border Ethereal Plane within 60 feet in a white shimmering outline.

entries.name: Targeted for Death
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can target a creature for death. You choose an undead, devil, or fiend creature that you can see within 30 feet of you. As a bonus action you can teleport to an unoccupied square adjacent to that creature.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Divine Strike
entries: At 8th level, you gain the ability to infuse your weapon attacks with divine energy that delivers celestial radiance. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra 1d8 radiant damage to the target. When you reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to 2d8.

entries.name: Seeker of Souls
entries: At 17th level, you gain the ability to seek out spirits on the Ethereal Plane, and help to send them on their way.

items: Ethereal Vision: You can see 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when you are on the material plane and vice versa.

Ethereal Walker: You can enter the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa. You are visible on the Material Plane while you are in the Border Ethereal, and vice versa, yet you can't affect or be affected by anything on the other plane.

data.name: Dead Gods and Undead Monsters
entries: Creatures, Monsters and other NPCs

entries.name: Bog Stronach
entries: A stronach is thought to be a piece of a dead god that has separated from its solidified corpse floating in the cosmos and that has found its way to the surface of the world, usually by being pulled through a gate in a random event. A stronach has no sapience but is imbued with latent magic.

When a stronach ends up in a location with moisture, over time it will leach the area of nutrients and create a bog. A bog stronach will begin to mindlessly attempt to create entities in its own image, likely a vestigial trait of godhood. Since it can't create true clones it sends out runners, much like rhizomes on a plant, that grow aberrant facsimiles of the stronach.

Stronach clones absorb nutrients and magic energy to feed the parent. One way they do this is by producing pearls, rough granite-like spheres with iridescent interiors that are eventually absorbed by the stronach for their energy. The most fascinating thing about these pearls is their magical homing quality. Stomach pearls are highly sought after by navigators the world over. It is relatively easy to harvest a pearl by damaging the clone that produced it to a certain point. However, a pearl is rendered useless if its clone is destroyed. Although the stronach is mindless, it has defenses, as do its clones. And while a bog stronach and its clones are one organism, they are treated like separate creatures for combat.

Stronachs affect chaos in their environment, magic in their presence is unpredictable and proximity to one for an extended period of time can cause madness. Stronach clones grow tentacles that grasp, constrict, and attempt to drown threats.

entries.name: Stronach Pearls
entries: A stronach pearl, or compass pearl, is a wondrous item that is used as a navigation tool by seafarers. Artisans grind off the rough exterior and tumble the pearl within into perfect spheres. A pearl is always drawn towards the location it was harvested if it is on the same plane. The larger the pearl, the stronger the attraction. The largest pearls can even propel becalmed sailing ships, albeit only in one direction. Stronach pearls have other magical qualities too, that vary by the stronach that produced it.

entries.name: Sea Stronach
entries: A stronach that ends up in the sea acts much like those that end up on land. It feeds itself by producing absorbing nutrients from its environment. A sea stronach has less effect on its surroundings due to the diluting nature of the water it is submerged in. There is an effect on magic around any stronach, but their effects rarely reach the surface. A sea stronach also produces less clones and thus fewer pearls. Its small pearls have little value for navigation to seafarers and its larger ones can prove an outright danger to small ships in rough seas.

entries.name: Dry Stronach
entries: There is a spot in an eastern desert that has an unexplained anti-magic field. It is thought that it is caused by a stronach buried deep within the dunes. Unable to absorb nutrients and moisture, it can only attract magic. It is unknown if it produces clones or pearls.

entries.caption: Weird Magic Table
rows: Your spell fails and uses up a spell slot unless it is a cantrip
You must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or become confused until the end of next turn
You must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or become confused until the start of next turn
You must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or take 10 (3d6) psychic damage and areknocked prone. On a success you take half damage and are not knocked prone
You must succeed on a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or 7 (2d6) psychic damage and are knockedprone. On a success you take half damage and are not knocked prone
You must succeed on a DC 11 Wisdom saving throw or you suffer 3 (1d6) psychic damage and areknocked prone
The target of your spell is chosen randomly from all creatures in a 25-foot radius sphere centeredanywhere on your target (DM's choice if larger than medium), including your target
The target of your spell is chosen randomly from all creatures in a 20-foot radius sphere centeredanywhere on your target (DM's choice if larger than medium), including your target
The target of your spell is chosen randomly from all creatures in a 15-foot radius sphere centeredanywhere on your target (DM's choice if larger than medium), including your target
The target of your spell is chosen randomly from all creatures in a 10-foot radius sphere centeredanywhere on your target (DM's choice if larger than medium), including your target

You cast a random spell 1 level higher than the spell you cast using the same verbal, somatic andmaterial components, if any, and it replaces the spell you cast. If you cast your highest level, itbecomes a random spell from that level

You cast a random spell 1 level lower than the spell you cast using the same verbal, somatic andmaterial components, if any, and it replaces the spell you cast. If you cast a cantrip, it fizzles and fails
You must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or you are pulled 10 feet closer to the stronach
You must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or you are pushed 10 feet away from the stronach
Your spell fails but it does not use up a spell slot
No effect. You cast your spell as normal
Your spell does not use up a spell slot

entries.name: Clones of a Dead Diety
entries: These mockeries of life are the offspring of a dead god and produce gems that are coveted the world over

entries.name: Stronach Clone
entries: Stronach clones are mindless creations of a stronach. They appear to be a way for the dead god to nurture itself through some instinctive method of self-preservation. When a god dies and floats in the cosmos it is inert. When circumstances allow it to find a plane rich in life and magic, some spark is triggered and over time extensions of the stronach reach out into its new environment to collect whatever energy it can find and absorb.

The result is a clone that resembles a cross between an aberrant creature and a plant. Stronach clones are tethered to the stronach by a stone-like fiber underground that is virtually impossible to sever. Because of this, clones have limited movement but whatever movement they have is relative to their age and size. Once a clone reaches a certain age, it withers and dies and is replaced by a new growth.

All clones absorb energy from their environment in the forms of elemental power, magic, and minerals. They concentrate these elements into gem-like spheres called pearls. The older the clone, the larger a pearl it will produce.

After a time, the pearl is absorbed by the host and the process begins anew. It is during this time that some have learned to harvest these pearls, at great risk. Since the clones are not defenseless.

Stronach clones have tentacles and a sightless eyelike organ that spits acid to scare predators away. They are excellent grapplers and will attempt to grab and drown any creature brave enough to attempt to harvest pearls from them. They may be blind but the have tremorsense that allows them to be aware of anything or anyone approaching them or the stronach.
Regardless of the risks, a nine-inch pearl from a mature clone can fetch over 32,000 gp for those brave enough to steal from a dead god and its blind minions.

entries.name: Bellewyn
entries: Bellewynn are aberrant undead originally created by a brilliant but naïve wizard, Artimus Bellewynn, who spent the latter part of his life developing a ritual spell to join an animated body that had no spirit with a ghost, a spirit that had no body. The sage pondered that the marriage would create a symbiotic relationship that could solve both entities’ deficiencies and create a complete productive being with the ghost’s personality. He imagined an eternally grateful creature beholding to the wizard that would staff his estate and that he could perhaps even mentor to learn, or relearn, magic, whatever the case being in their previous life.

As it turned out, he was eventually successful in conjoining the creatures. However, the ghosts were quickly driven into madness by their new prison, no longer able to escape into the ethereal plane, and were soon contaminated by the dark magic that had animated their shells in the first place. The skeletons, zombies and mummies had all been created by necromancy or ancient magic that bore no relationship to the wizard’s comparatively altruistic endeavors. The results were insane evil creatures that overwhelmed the mage, destroyed him, and escaped his tower.

Myths grew up around these relatively rare creatures that roamed the countryside. There were so few of these so-called bellewyn that the legends might have died there if the rumors had not reached the ears of a powerful necromancer.
Tantalized by the potential of such an esoteric ritual, the sorcerer traveled to the wizard’s tower in search of his notes.
The necromancer’s success is evident in the proliferation of bellewynn throughout the world today.

Bellewynn are dangerous. They have no loyalties, are insane and exist only to destroy. They retain most of the qualities of both their hosts and although they are easy to hit, they have many resistances, and they are hard to kill. They give the impression of being slow moving when they shamble along the ground, but they can fly and do so at twice their walking speed.

entries.name: Fenghast
entries: A fenghast is an aquatic ghast that resembles a ghoul but is more resilient. It is an emaciated flesh eater that can poison a victim with its stench and paralyze it with its claws. Most fenghasts have enough of a larynx to speak but not many are interested in anything they have to say.

entries.name: Carbon Hag
entries: A carbon hag is a night hag gone mad by proximity to a stronach. Leeched magics and melanin leave the hag black and insane and stranded in a world of madness. A carbon hag has lost its heartstone. It carries a stronach pearl in its place, which it believes to be its heartstone. As a result, it can no longer plane shift and is not immune to disease, but it has gained the ability to command certain undead creatures.
A carbon hag can see into the Ethereal Plane and has learned to control entities in the spirit world. The hag has become a necromancer of sorts by circumstance.

It is still a malevolent creature that enjoys the downfall and mental anguish of others >above all and has retained its ability to shapeshift. While its mind has been altered, a carbon hag still retains enough intelligence to scheme and connive in order to create pain and chaos among mortals, its favorite prey.

entries.name: Sapient Salamanders
entries: Often mistaken for lizardfolk, these salamander humanoids have smooth skin and are lacking the scales of their reptilian cousins.

entries.name: Bog Folk
entries: Bog folk are sapient salamander humanoids that are at home in both water and on land. They are smooth-skinned and have no scales unlike lizardfolk, for whom they are sometimes mistaken. Bog folk are shorter than their cold-blooded cousins and have several other differences as well. They can regenerate a limb if it is lost, and their skin exudes a poison that acts as a defense mechanism.
Bog folk are not related to elemental salamanders (frost or fire).

They are not known for their intelligence and rely on wisdom to navigate the bogs and swamps they tend to inhabit. Bog folk call themselves caudatans and live in small tribes of up to two dozen individuals led by charismatic olm or axolotl caudatans – white bog folk with red gill stalks who are innate magic users.

Bog folk are carnivores but since they have no teeth to speak of, prefer insects, slugs and fish over large hunks of reptile or mammal meat, unless it is stewed. They have a strong enough bite but rely on a ridge plate instead of teeth or fangs. The largest members of their tribes become warriors and raid or trade for steel weapons which they use to good effect. Since they do not have great natural armor, their warriors – or brutes, as they are known – usually wield shields to aid in their defense.
Bog folk do not have great eyesight and lack darkvision.

Because of the position of their small eyes on their heads, they only see what they are facing. They must move their bodies to face what they wish to see. If something stands still in their peripheral vision, it becomes invisible to the bog folk.

Overall, caudatans are pragmatic and neutral in their morality, giving preference to their survival over concerns of others. They will trade and interact with strangers but are wary and ready to kill and likely eat them if they perceive a threat.
Only rabbits should go down rabbit holes... Unless you know the right spells.
Adventuring without magic items is akin to sailing without a sail.

entries.name: Sword of the Apostate
entries: The Sword of the Apostate was created to untether a particular group of zealots from their deity to defeat them.

The long, sharp steel stiletto-like weapon is less flexible than most rapiers and was designed to assassinate the target in one stroke, sliding it up through the kidney into the heart. It works effectively as a standard rapier, however, in face-to-face combat.

A Sword of the Apostate can be upgraded. At level 5, a player can have an uncommon version upgraded to a rare blade at qualified armorer for the price of the new blade. At level 10, a player may have its rare blade upgraded to a very rare, and at level 15, to a legendary. Rumors say a unique sentient artifact version of the Sword of the Apostate, the original blade, exists in the world, and that all others are based upon it, but if it does exist, it has not been seen in centuries.

entries.name: Sword of the Apostate Rarity
entries: As a Sword of the Apostate is upgraded, its properties are changed at rarities +1, +2, and +3.
The DC of the weapon's features is determined by its rarity, as indicated in the Sword of the Apostate Upgrade table.
Additionally, the +2 and +3 rarities of this weapon gain the following feature:

{@b Whirlwind}. This sword has 1 charge, which is regained at dawn each day. As an action you can speak a command word to target a creature within 60 feet. A whirlwind forms around the target but does not impede their sight. The target must succeed on a DC 17 Constitution saving throw or be deafened and silenced for 1 minute. While the target is affected in this way it can't cast a spell that includes a verbal component. As an action, the target can repeat the saving throw to end the effect.

data.name: Adventure! The Harried Harvester
entries: A Fifth Edition adventure for 5 characters with an average party level (APL) of 6. It can be run as a 2-4 hour one-shot or incorporated into a longer game or campaign. It is suitable for a wilderness area of forest that transitions into an acidic bog, with the nearest major settlement several hours away.

entries.name: Background
entries: Khellach (pronounced KEL’-lick) village is known for its compass pearls. These rare navigational devices are in demand the world over and the Khellach stronach, a mysterious object, has produced pearls up to 8 inches in diameter.

The village’s chief pearl harvester, Fen Fenneck, has been kidnapped by a tribe of bog folk that have moved into the swamp north of the village. The villagers know this because when they went searching for him, one of these creatures, a pale salamander humanoid with red feathered gill stalks, a shaman with a gnarled staff and a necklace of small animal skulls, appeared out of the swamp and told them in stilted Common to “go home” that “him work for Glip, now”. The shaman naively added that Fenneck was “happy, no torture, no big cuts on Fen-ick back” then retreated into the mists.

Concerned for their harvester (and their livelihood) the village elders have put out a call for help. A messenger has been sent by horse to the nearest garrison. In the meantime, they are offering 2500 gp from their harvest treasury, as well as meals and accommodations at the Nestle Inn, for successful return of their man.

entries.name: Hook 1 World Heritage Site
entries: When the adventurers stop in a settlement an NPC suggests since they are in the region, they should check out the renowned Khellach stronach if they have the time.

It is a well-known anomaly in these parts that produces the world famous stronach pearls. The three-hour trek up a logging road into the woods is worth the trip and the village of Khellach boasts a fine inn.

entries.name: Hook 2 Tarnished Pilgrimage
entries: The adventurers meet a group of priests returning from a pilgrimage to the Khellach stronach. They believe the stronach, a great strange monolith, is a divine piece of a dead god. On their last day at the inn, they overheard that an important figure in the village had disappeared, and the mayor was desperately seeking aid to find their man. The village appeared to have the financial means to hire a group.

entries.name: Hook 3 Operation Interrupted
entries: While traveling, the adventurers encounter a troupe of cavalry trotting in the opposite direction. The captain stops the adventurers and after assessing them by their appearance, she attempts to second the group into taking an urgent message to a village called Khellach. She explains the village has requested military assistance to help with a kidnapping, and although they are on their way, she must make a detour to deal with a critical goblin issue closer to base first.

entries.name: Hook 4 Tavern Talk
entries: While the adventurers are in a tavern, a breathless man barges in and announces to the place that there is trouble in Khellach, a secluded village several hours away. The mayor is looking for help and is paying well to sell swords.

Most of the other customers look interested when he mentions coin but quickly turn back to their ales when it is followed by swords. If the adventurers speak with him, he explains that Khellach is a wealthy town, and he overheard the mayor mention 2500 gold pieces for the return of a kidnapped harvester.

entries.name: Hook 5 Traveling Merchant
entries: The adventurers encounter a traveling merchant on a wagon recently returning from a stop in the secluded village of Khellach. He relays the news that one of their townsfolk was kidnapped by salamander people and the village leaders have offered a hefty purse for his return.

entries.name: Part 1: The Arrival
entries: When the adventurers arrive in Khellach, it is overcast. The village is small, but the homes are attractive and well maintained. The main building is a stone inn on one side of the only road, a two-story structure with ornate stonework and a wide iron-bound oak door. As they arrive, they are greeted by the mayor and others. When they enter the village, read the following:

You arrive at the village on an overcast day. On your right are small but attractive homes, well-built with landscaped yards and fruit trees. You can smell the verdant foliage, rich and green from the moisture. A well-worn path leads past the houses into a bog where a low-lying mist mirrors the clouds overhead. To the left is a two-story stone inn with a steep tiled roof. A varnished wooden sign hangs in front from wrought iron hangers and reads, “The Nestle Inn.” An overweight but agile human with salt and pepper hair and a trimmed graying beard bustles out the oak door and gingerly hops down two wooden steps, followed by a dark-haired, copper-skinned tiefling woman wearing an apron, and dapper halfling in a tan suit over a burgundy waistcoat. “Welcome to Khellack! My name is Oghman Mullar and I am the mayor of this fine village!” He pokes a thumb over his shoulder at the woman behind him and announces, “This is Margan Karzoth, the owner of the Nestle Inn,” who nods at you with what might be a permanent frown. The portly mayor turns to his left and tilts his head toward the well-dressed halfling and continues, “and this is Mr. Goldbottom, our patron and village treasurer”. The smiling halfling tips his bowler hat to you, spilling out curly blond locks before replacing on his rather large head. “Are we correct in assuming you are here to help?” asks the mayor, with an expectant look on his face.

Regardless of how the party answers, the mayor invites the party inside the Nestle Inn and once seated, the tiefling brings over refreshments while Mullar tells the adventurers a bit about the stronach, the pearls it makes, and informs them their chief pearl harvester, Fen Fenneck, has been kidnapped by bog folk. After describing their predicament, the mayor offers the adventurers 2500 gp to find and return their man.
He may also add that the militia is on the way and will take care of the problem, however, the town is not willing to wait and risk something happening to their livelihood.

When the adventurers accept, Ohgman explains that the adventurers will have to harvest a pearl from the stronach with which to bribe the bog folk for the man. Once they succeed, the party should head north through the swamp, past a stone circle until they find the bog folk village. The mayor insists that the larger the pearl the adventurers can offer, the better the chance of a successful negotiation.
Oghman asks the adventurers to arrange a trade or otherwise deal with the bog folk but to retrieve Fenneck at all costs.
He explains that only the clones produce pearls and the larger the clone, the better chance it will have a large pearl.

He cautions the adventurers not to attack the stronach itself as no good has ever come from doing so and it is their livelihood, after all. Although most clones produce pearls, only the biggest clones are guaranteed to have one.

entries.name: Roleplaying Oghman:
entries: The mayor is friendly but anxious. He is downplaying the dangers of the stronach and the bog folk. He also knows there are other threats in the bog. He will not outright lie to the adventurers, but he might be evasive in his answers if he thinks they will turn him down. If they question him for information, you can have them perform DC 12 Wisdom (Insight) checks to detect if he is being fully forthcoming with his information. Successful Charisma (Persuasion) or (Intimidation) checks of increasing difficulty will provide the following information from the mayor:

entries.caption: What Oghman knows:
rows: The stronach is a piece of a dead god that tumbled through the stone circle a century or more ago.
The stronach feeds on magic and casting spells is unpredictable in its presence.
The stronach is not alive but reacts when attacked.
Undead have been known to wander the bog. It was the village’s biggest concern before the arrival of the bog folk.
The stronach has made the town filthy rich. A 2500 gp reward may seem like a fair amount of coin, but they stand to lose far more if they do not get their harvester back.

entries.name: Roleplaying Goldbottom:
entries: The halfling is a sly businessman and stands to lose the most if Fenneck is not safely returned. He is deathly afraid of the stronach and he, like many of the villagers, will not venture into the bog under any circumstances. He is more apt to be truthful if questioned directly about the dangers but all he has is second hand information. If he is asked anything directly about the quest by one of the adventurers, he might tell them he has heard that undead appear in the bog when there are eerie lights in the marsh mists. Goldbottom is the village treasurer. He will pay them a 500 gp deposit up front if they wish and the balance when Fenneck is returned.

entries.name: Roleplaying Karzoth:
entries: The tiefling frowns a lot for a bartender and inn proprietor.

Although she has a server, a tall human woman, she serves the adventurers’ table herself. She will offer them a meal and rooms for the night if they accept the quest. If questioned, she has the same information as the mayor but will only respond to the same Persuasion DC. If an adventurer uses Intimidation on Karzoth, add +5 to the DC. On a failure, she laughs and walks away.
When the adventurers accept the quest and are ready, they head up the path from the inn into the bog with instructions to look for a pond with a strange object in the middle.

entries.name: Part 2: The Acquisition
entries: As soon as the adventurers leave the village, the forest recedes, and they enter the bog. Read the following:

You enter a soggy, swamp-like region dominated by coarse weeds and stunted trees. A well-worn path leads you forward under an overcast sky into a misty marsh. The trail is paved with old stone and is easy to follow, even in the gloom. Low-lying water buzzing with clouds of insects gathers in reed-choked pools to your right and left.

After about twenty minutes the sound of insects ceases. The paved path splits and follows the edge of the pond around its entire circumference. The pond is 90-feet wide by 110-feet deep and is dominated by a gargantuan object near its center that is partially visible above the surface of the water.
When you have the map ready, read the following:

A gargantuan alien shape lies sunken in the middle of a stagnant pond ahead of you. Strange markings line the mass of the dark object that is not under water. Bubbles pop to the surface in small areas surrounding the object above grey shapes that lurk just below them. A cobblestone path follows the pool’s edge all the way around to the other side.
The bubbles indicate the locations of the stronach clones

The clones are tethered to the stronach under the mud at the bottom of the pond which is 15 feet deep around the stronach. The depth of the pond elsewhere, corresponds with the size of the clone. For example, it is 3 feet deep by a small clone, 5 feet deep by a medium clone, and 10 feet deep by a large clone. A successful DC 16 Intelligence (Religion) or (History) check will reveal that the massive shape is a piece of a dead god known as a stronach. If a character exceeds the check by 5, they also recall it likely arrived from the cosmos through a portal. A successful DC 12 Intelligence (Arcana) or (Nature) check will identify the shapes under the bubbles as stronach clones.

Combat in the pond is considered to be underwater. Roll Initiative as soon as a character enters the pool or otherwise attacks. The stronach clones act on the same initiative. The stronach has no initiative or actions but reacts to damage it receives without restriction. In addition, any time a creature casts a spell within 60 feet of the Stronach, roll on the weird magic table. Apply the result immediately after the spell is cast but before it takes effect.

Each stronach clone can have a maximum of 1 pearl. To harvest a pearl, a character must be adjacent to a clone that has less than half of its maximum hit points and at least 1 hit point. It takes an action to harvest a pearl. When the character uses their action to harvest a pearl, roll a d10 on the appropriate table for the result.
When the adventurers are ready, ideally with a pearl, they continue their search for Fenneck.

entries.name: Part 3: The Marvelous Miss Mavel
GM Note
entries: A carbon hag believes the adventurers have her heartstone and wants it. She is mad but lucid enough to use guile before violence and shapeshifts when she senses their approach. The hag appears as a local commoner female and tries to find a way to swindle the adventurers out of their pearl. She will claim to be a villager searching for something. She may suggest the burning bowl is a prayer to a deity to aid in her quest. It is, in fact, part of a ritual to help her summon and control undead. If the party gives up any information about their quest, the hag will use that to bolster her illusion. If they mention Fenneck, for example, she may claim she is the missing man’s wife and is searching for him, or if they mention the negotiation of the pearl for Fenneck, she could say she knows the bog folk’s ways, that the bog folk are lying and only she can retrieve Fenneck and volunteer to handle the negotiation if they hand her the pearl. In any case, if the adventurers see through her guise with a successful DC {@dc 18} Intelligence ({@skill investigation}) check or disbelieve her story with a successful DC {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check, she will summon fenghasts from the surrounding mists and attack.
Not long after the adventurers leave the stronach pond they should find a stone circle in the mists. As they approach read the following:

Pools of stagnant water begin to encroach on the stone path. The mist is thicker here and glows with a sickly green. Directly ahead you see a circle of eight round stones surrounding a square plinth holding a bowl with a dull flame flickering, lending some light to the overcast gloom. Beyond the flaming bowl you notice a shape moving within the stone circle.

As the party approaches, they observe a woman dressed in commoner clothes that appears to be concerned and relieved at their arrival. She claims her name is Mavel (which is true; the hag’s real name is Mavel Muggonag) and she is searching.

entries.name: Roleplaying Mavel:
entries: Her overall demeanor is one of a concerned and determined woman on a lonely quest. If asked what she is searching for, she will not answer directly until she gets information from the adventurers. She may respond with a question of her own instead. She will say she is from the village however she does not know the name of the village nor the name of anyone in it. She will probe the adventurers for information to use in her story.

The carbon hag will maintain the illusion as long as it serves her but will attack if the adventurers leave without giving or promising her a pearl, or if they see through her illusion. When this happens, rollinitiative. The fenghasts appear during the second round of combat on their group Initiative.

entries.name: Encounter
entries: Marvelous Miss Mavel (6300 XP, CR 10): 1x {@creature carbon hag|GP_USRoR}, 3 x {@creature fenghasts|GP_USRoR}

entries.name: GM Note
entries: Fenghasts can appear from any mist marked ‘5’.

When the carbon hag is destroyed, its body disappears to another plane with its soul bag, leaving behind its material goods. A search of Mavel’s belongings reveals a damaged 1” Stronach Pearl and a Scarf of the Raven.

entries.name: Part 4: Finding Fenneck
entries: Regardless of the path the adventurers take from the stone circle; they eventually end up at the desired location. The landscape is much the same. It is still overcast but the mists have disappeared and there are a few more stunted trees.
The bog has turned into marshland with reeds choking what appears to be deeper water than the stagnant ponds they have passed.
The adventurers should not have much trouble locating a village of mud huts about an hour north of Khellach. When they do, read the following:

Ahead you see half a dozen mut huts on a narrow strip of land between reed-choked marshes. To the left a large water buffalo grazes in the water. A smooth-skinned reptile-looking humanoid stands by the nearest hut facing in your general direction. They are armed and appear to be a guard but have not noticed you yet as you are behind a pair of trees. In front of the largest hut, a campfire blazes and two more reptilian creatures sit beside it in rough chairs. One is very pale and wears a necklace of animal skulls. He holds a gnarled staff in one hand. The other is darker and much taller, wielding a sword and a shield. A fourth creature of their kind stands on a dock beyond them to the right, mending a net. You notice movement in the doorways of some of the other huts.

The nearest guard is a bog folk. The pale salamander humanoid is a bog folk shaman. His companion is a bog folk brute. Only the shaman and an off-map bog folk witch speak Common. The other bog folk only speak Aquan. The leader of the village is the shaman with its second-in-command being the witch. The witch is guarding Fenneck, who is tied up on a hide bed in the large hut. The bog folk have a good idea why the adventurers are there but are willing to listen if the adventurers do not attack immediately. If they do approach, the shaman directs the adventurers to stop once they get level with the first hut.

If the adventurers attempt to negotiate for Fenneck, the bog folk shaman, Glip, will trade him for a pearl on a successful DC 30 Charisma (Persuasion) check. Use the chart below to determine any modifier based on any pearl they recovered from the stronach and offer up in the negotiation. If the adventurers do not have a pearl, Glip will not negotiate. The hag’s damaged pearl is useless.
If negotiations break down, or the adventurers bypass negotiations altogether, roll initiative.

entries.name: Encounter
entries: Bog Folk Fury (4000 XP, CR 8): 1x {@creature bog folk witch|GP_USRoR}, 1 x {@creature bog folk shaman|GP_USRoR}, 2 x {@creature bog folk brute|GP_USRoR|bog folk brutes}, 4 x {@creature bog folk|GP_USRoR}.

Once both the shaman and the witch have been reduced to 0 hit points, the remaining bog folk will take flight using their swim speed, underwater to avoid missiles. Fenneck can be found in reasonable shape in the large hut. {@creature Fen Fenneck|GP_USRoR} is a 6’2” red-haired military veteran with expertise in grappling who wears a {@item Cape of Acid Resistance|GP_USRoR} to aid in pearl harvesting. The bog folk took it from him, but it is crumpled in a corner of the hut nearby. He is angry that he was captured by the small salamander people but very happy to be freed.

A search of the hut will reveal 2x {@item Potion of Greater Healing||Potions of Greater Healing} and an {@item Obsidian Coffin of Gentle Repose|GP_USRoR}. A search of the other huts will turn up 3x crocodile hides (3 gp), 1x albino crocodile hide (15 gp), and 17x small snake skins (1 gp). The bog folk appear to have no use for coin.

entries.name: Congratulations!
entries: The adventurers have succeeded in recovering Fen Fenneck.
The adventurers and Fenneck can now make the 1-hour trek back to Khellach and pick up their reward. Hopefully, they will not run into any more trouble on their way through the bog!

entries.name: GM Note:
entries: If you wish to run a random encounter or two on the way back to the village, feel free to use some of the monsters included in this volume of Unearthed Spoils. Rumor has it that bellewynn undead are roaming the bogs, or maybe the adventurers would now like a shot at a larger pearl!
Fen Fenneck will gladly join in to help his saviors on his return home.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The clone has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The stronach regains 30 hit points at the start of its turn. If the stronach takes radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the stronach's next turn. The stronach is destroyed only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Aberrant Chaos
entries: Whenever a spell is cast within 120 feet of the stronach, roll on the {@table weird magic table|GP_USRoR} for the result.

reaction.name: Pulse of a Dead God
entries: When the stronach is hit by an attack, or is the target of a spell that results in damage, it sends out a pulse in a 150-foot radius sphere. Each creature in the sphere that is not a clone of the stronach must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or take 16 ({@damage 3d10}) psychic damage.
Legendary Resistance (3/Day). If the stronach fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Defensive Expert
entries: Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on the clone's ranged attack rolls.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The clone has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Stronach Pearl
entries: There is a 80 percent chance that this clone has a 0.5" - 1" pearl that can be extracted as an action by a creature within 5 feet of it, when the clone reaches less than one half of its hit points.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The clone makes up to one tentacle attack and one acid jet attack.

action.name: Acid Jet
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 15/45 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) acid damage.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}). Until the grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained} and the tentacle can't be used to attack.

trait.name: Defensive Expert
entries: Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on the clone's ranged attack rolls.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The clone has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Stronach Pearl
entries: There is a 90 percent chance that this clone has a 1.5" - 3" pearl that can be extracted as an action by a creature within 5 feet of it, when the clone reaches less than one half of its hit points.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The clone makes up to two tentacle attacks and one acid jet attack.

action.name: Acid Jet
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 15/45 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) acid damage.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}).
Until the grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained} and the tentacle can't be used to attack. The clone has two tentacles, each of which can grapple one target.

trait.name: Defensive Expert
entries: Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on the clone's ranged attack rolls.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The clone has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Stronach Pearl
entries: This clone has a 4 inch or greater pearl that can be extracted as an action by a creature within 5 feet of it, when the clone reaches less than one half of its hit points. If the clone is reduced to 0 hp the pearl is destroyed.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The clone makes up to two tentacle attacks and one acid jet attack.

action.name: Acid Jet
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 15/45 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) acid damage.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}).
Until the grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained} and the tentacle can't be used to attack. The clone has three tentacles, each of which can grapple one target.

monster.name: Skeletal Bellewyn
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Supernatural Combatant
entries: The bellewynn uses its Charisma ability modifier for attack and damage rolls.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Withering Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 4d6 + 3}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Horrifying Visage
entries: Each non-undead creature within 60 ft. of the bellewynn that can see it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the {@condition frightened} condition on itself on a success. If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to this bellewynn's Horrifying Visage for the next 24 hours.

monster.name: Mummy Bellewyn
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Supernatural Combatant
entries: The bellewynn uses its Charisma ability modifier for attack and damage rolls.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bellewynn can use its Dreadful Glare and makes one attack with its rotting fist or withering touch.

action.name: Withering Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d6 + 4}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Rotting Fist {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be cursed with mummy rot. The cursed target can't regain hit points, and its hit point maximum decreases by 10 ({@dice 3d6}) for every 24 hours that elapses. If the curse reduces the target's hit point maximum to 0, the target dies, and its body turn to dust. the curse lasts until removed by the {@spell remove curse} spell or other magic.

action.name: Dreadful Glare
entries: The bellewynn targets one creature it can see within 60 feet of it. If the target can see the bellewynn, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw against this magic or become {@condition frightened} until the end of the bellewynn's next turn. If the target fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it is also {@condition paralyzed} for the same duration. A target that succeeds on the saving throw is immune to the Dreadful Glare of all mummy bellewynn for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Horrifying Visage
entries: Each non-undead creature within 60 ft. of the bellewynn that can see it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the {@condition frightened} condition on itself on a success. If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to this bellewynn's Horrifying Visage for the next 24 hours.

monster.name: Zombie Bellewyn
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Supernatural Combatant
entries: The bellewynn uses its Charisma ability modifier for attack and damage rolls.

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the bellewynn to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the bellewynn drops to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Withering Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 4d6 + 3}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Horrifying Visage
entries: Each creature within 60 ft. of the bellewynn that can see it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the {@condition frightened} condition on itself on a success. If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to this bellewynn's Horrifying Visage for the next 24 hours. Undead automatically succeed on the saving throw.

trait.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 5 ft. of the fenghast must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the fenghast's Stench for 24 hours.

trait.name: Turn Defiance
entries: The fenghast and any aquatic ghouls within 30 ft. of it have advantage on saving throws against effects that turn undead.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature other than an undead, it must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

resist.note: from nonmagical weapons that aren't silvered

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Command Undead
entries: As a bonus action, the hag targets one undead creature it can see within 30 feet. The target must make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target must obey the hag's commands for the next 24 hours, or until the hag uses this ability again, is {@condition incapacitated} or is destroyed.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The hag has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Carbon Hag Items
entries: A carbon hag carries two very rare magic items that she must craft for herself If either object is lost, the night hag will go to great lengths to retrieve it, as creating a new tool takes time and effort.
Stronach Pearl: This iridescent pale gem allows a carbon hag to command undead while it is in her possession.

Soul Bag: When an evil humanoid dies as a result of a night hag's Nightmare Haunting, the hag catches the soul in this black sack made of stitched flesh. A soul bag can hold only one evil soul at a time, and only the carbon hag who crafted the bag can catch a soul with it.
Crafting a soul bag takes 7 days and a humanoid sacrifice (whose flesh is used to make the bag).

action.name: Claws (Hag Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Change Shape
entries: The hag magically polymorphs into a Small or Medium female humanoid, or back into her true form. Her statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment she is wearing or carrying isn't transformed.
She reverts to her true form if she dies.

action.name: Withering Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) necrotic damage.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The bog folk can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Limited Vision
entries: The bog folk can only make an attack of opportunity against a creature that hits it with a melee attack and has not left its line of sight.

trait.name: Poisonous Body
entries: A creature that touches the bog folk, or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it, takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bog folk makes two melee attacks, one with its short sword and one with its tail.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Short Sword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

entries: The bog folk can breathe air and water.

entries: The bog folk can only make an attack of opportunity against a creature that hits it with a melee attack and has not left its line of sight.

trait.name: Poisonous Body
entries: A creature that touches the bog folk, or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it, takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The bog folk regains 1 hit point at the start of its turn. If the bog folk takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the bog folk's next turn. The bog folk dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bog folk makes two melee attacks, one with its longsword and one with its tail.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) piercing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage, or Ranged Weapon Attack: {@hit 5} to hit, range 30/120 ft., {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

footerEntries: 1st Level (4 slots): cure wounds, entangle, fog cloud

headerEntries: The bog folk's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following warlock spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The bog folk can breathe both air and water.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The bog folk has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Limited Vision
entries: The bog folk can only make an attack of opportunity against a creature that hits it with a melee attack and has not left its line of sight.

trait.name: Poisonous Body
entries: A creature that touches the bog folk, or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it, takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The bog folk regains 1 hit point at the start of its turn. If the bog folk takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the bog folk's next turn. The bog folk dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bog folk makes two melee attacks, one with its longsword and one with its tail.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) piercing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Eldritch Blast (Cantrip)
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 6} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage.

action.name: Poison Splash (2/Day)
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 6} to hit, range 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d12}) poison damage.

trait.name: Cloak of Acid Resistance
entries: Fenneck gains resistance to acid damage when he wears this cloak (shown in the stat block).

trait.name: Close-Quarters Specialist
entries: Fenneck has advantage on attack rolls against a creature he is grappling.

trait.name: Marine Combatant
entries: Being partially in water does not count as difficult terrain for Fenneck and being underwater does not impose disadvantage on his weapon attacks.

trait.name: Veteran Brawler
entries: Fenneck's unarmed strikes are weapon attacks and use a {@damage d4} for damage.

trait.name: Grapple (Bonus Action)
entries: When Fenneck hits a creature with an unarmed strike on his turn, he can use a bonus action to attempt to grapple the target.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Fenneck makes two unarmed strikes.

action.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage or Ranged Weapon Attack {@hit 5} to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: Fenneck adds his proficiency bonus to his AC against one melee attack that would hit him.

spell.name: Enlighten
entries: You touch one willing creature. Once before the spell ends, the target can make an ability check of its choice with advantage. Once the check is made the spell ends.

spell.name: Poison Splash
entries: A small sphere of pale green jelly shoots toward a target within range and bursts in a spray of poison. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 2d12} poison damage.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d12} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Premature Celebration
entries: Choose a creature within range that you can see. The target makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a failure it sees the next attack it makes as wildly successful with the victim exploding into sparkling particles, whether it hits or misses. If the target has a feature that allows it to attack more than once, it does not use any remaining attacks that turn.

At the start of its next turn, the target can make the saving throw again. If it fails, it remains under the illusion. If it can see its original victim, it believes it is a new opponent and may attack it again, or a different target, with the same result.

spell.name: Probe Creature
entries: Choose a creature that you can see within range and analyze its true nature. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or you learn its creature type.

spell.name: Swamp Gas

components.m: a lake frond or a blade of sedge grass

entries: You create a 20-foot-radius sphere of pale-yellow mist centered on a point within range. The mist spreads around corners, and its area is lightly obscured. The mist lingers in the air for the duration.

Each creature that is completely within the mist at the start of its turn must make a Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 4d6} acid damage. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage.
A moderate wind (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses the mist after 4 rounds. A strong wind (at least 20 miles per hour) disperses it after 1 round.

spell.name: Transpose Lifeforce
entries: You touch a creature that has died within the last hour. The creature must be within 60 feet of a living plant that is Huge or larger. You draw the lifeforce from the plant and transfer it to that creature. It returns to life with {@dice 1d8} + your spellcasting modifier hit points.
The plant withers and dies unless it is Gargantuan or larger in size.

item.name: Sword of the Apostate
entries: This magical weapon deals an extra (3) {@damage 1d6} radiant damage when you hit a creature with it.

While attuned to this weapon, when you hit a target with a melee attack with it, the target must succeed on a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or lose its highest unused spell slot. On a success it loses its lowest spell slot. If the target has no spell slots, this feature has no effect. If the target is a cleric, druid, paladin, or shaman, it has disadvantage on the saving throw. The weapon regains this feature each day at dawn.

item.name: Cape of Acid Resistance
entries: Imbued with magical dust created from crushed black dragon scales, this cloak protects you from its vile breath. You have resistance to acid damage while you wear this cape.

item.name: Obsidian Coffin of Gentle Repose
entries: You touch a corpse or other remains with this item. The corpse or remains shrink and are absorbed into the object.

For the next tenday the contents are protected from decay and can't become undead. Speaking a command word and tapping the obsidian coffin against a surface will release the corpse or remains into an unoccupied adjacent space. If not released in this way, after 10 days the corpse or remains are automatically released into the nearest unoccupied space.

There is no way to open the miniature coffin. It can be destroyed by hitting it hard enough with a blunt metal or adamantine object and a successful DC 25 Strength check. If the coffin is destroyed in this way, so are any remains inside. The coffin always weighs 1 lb.

item.name: Potion of Shielding
entries: You gain temporary hit points when you drink this potion.
The number of temporary hit points depends on the potion's rarity, as shown in the Potions of Shielding table. Whatever its potency, the potion's blue liquid glimmers when agitated.

item.name: Scarf of the Raven
entries: You can wear this scarf either as a shawl or as a head and face cover. When you wear this item to cover both your head and face, you appear undead and your life force is undetectable. However, you are not subject to turn undead or any spells or magical effects that affect undead. You can stop this effect by exposing your head or face.

While attuned to this item undead are not hostile to you until you damage them or are observed to have caused them to be damaged in some way. An undead can also become hostile to you if it attempts to command you and you do not obey its command.

item.name: Sentinel Spirit Lantern
entries: A spirit is trapped within this lantern. While attuned to this item and holding it in dim light or darkness, you can command the spirit as a bonus action to shed a bright, ghostly light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. Any undead creatures within the affected area will glow. Any {@condition invisible} creature within the affected area must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) saving throw or be revealed.
The light from this lantern penetrates the Ethereal Plane.
Any creature exposed in this manner becomes corporeal to you and can be attacked.
In addition, you have advantage on attack rolls against creatures glowing or exposed by this lantern.

The spirit is magically bound to the lantern and can't be harmed, turned, or raised from the dead while bound. If the spirit is released, which requires a 5th-level spell or higher, the lantern becomes non-magical. Until then it requires no oil or wick to function.

item.name: Stronach Pearl (small)
entries: If placed on a flat surface, this pearl will roll towards the location where it was harvested provided you are on the same plane. How fast it rolls and how many obstacles it can overcome are commensurate with its size.

Stronach pearls fascinate undead creatures. As an action, you can make a ranged attack using either your Strength or Dexterity modifier against an undead creature with a stronach pearl, one target, range 20/80. On a hit, the undead creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the start of your next turn.
A small stronach pearl can be used as ammunition in a sling with the above properties as well as the sling damage.

table.name: Weird Magic Table
table.caption: Weird Magic Table

You must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or become confused until the end of next turn
You must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or become confused until the start of next turn

You must succeed on a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or 7 (2d6) psychic damage and are knockedprone. On a success you take half damage and are not knocked prone
You must succeed on a DC 11 Wisdom saving throw or you suffer 3 (1d6) psychic damage and areknocked prone
The target of your spell is chosen randomly from all creatures in a 25-foot radius sphere centeredanywhere on your target (DM's choice if larger than medium), including your target
The target of your spell is chosen randomly from all creatures in a 20-foot radius sphere centeredanywhere on your target (DM's choice if larger than medium), including your target
The target of your spell is chosen randomly from all creatures in a 15-foot radius sphere centeredanywhere on your target (DM's choice if larger than medium), including your target
The target of your spell is chosen randomly from all creatures in a 10-foot radius sphere centeredanywhere on your target (DM's choice if larger than medium), including your target

You cast a random spell 1 level higher than the spell you cast using the same verbal, somatic andmaterial components, if any, and it replaces the spell you cast. If you cast your highest level, itbecomes a random spell from that level

You cast a random spell 1 level lower than the spell you cast using the same verbal, somatic andmaterial components, if any, and it replaces the spell you cast. If you cast a cantrip, it fizzles and fails
You must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or you are pulled 10 feet closer to the stronach
You must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or you are pushed 10 feet away from the stronach
Your spell fails but it does not use up a spell slot
No effect. You cast your spell as normal
Your spell does not use up a spell slot

subclassFeature.name: Repose Domain
entries: These lawful undertakers of the realm are not particularly benevolent. Clerics of Repose concern themselves with the matters of passing and ushering the spirit from the mortal world to the next. They abhor undead or anything that interferes with the natural course of the spirit in life and in death. Although children and the unwashed often fear these armed clergy, in their ubiquitous black and charcoal gray robes with symbols of death adorning them, the sage and experienced know that they bear no malice towards the average person. Only necromancers and those who deal in souls, such as devils and fiends need to fear their divine wrath.

They serve deities of the dead and as their service grows, they are granted powers that those who play with souls and the undead fear. Many of their orders produce special potions that do not heal but work as a prophylactic against death.

Clerics of Repose can raise the dead themselves but only do so to restore a lawful life to an unjust death, and always for a price. They are the undertakers of the realm and perform rites of passing on the battlefield and on deathbeds alike. The donations they receive for such services, and their potions, go towards maintaining their gothic temples where acolytes are trained in the esoteric divine domain of repose.

subclassFeature.name: Ken Judgment
entries: Starting when you choose this domain at 1st level, you become proficient with the Insight and Perception skills.

subclassFeature.name: Not Today
entries: At 1st level, you gain the ability to stabilize the dying by merely touching them. You learn the spare the dying cantrip if you do not know it already and can cast it as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Seek Undead
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to see the unliving in your midst. As an action, you present your holy symbol and invoke the power of the Plane of Death.

Every undead creature within 60 feet that is within your line of sight is revealed to you in an outline of golden shimmering waves. Additionally, your power will reveal undead creatures on the Ethereal Plane by revealing any creature on the Border Ethereal Plane within 60 feet in a white shimmering outline.

subclassFeature.name: Targeted for Death
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can target a creature for death. You choose an undead, devil, or fiend creature that you can see within 30 feet of you. As a bonus action you can teleport to an unoccupied square adjacent to that creature.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Strike
entries: At 8th level, you gain the ability to infuse your weapon attacks with divine energy that delivers celestial radiance. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra 1d8 radiant damage to the target. When you reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to 2d8.

subclassFeature.name: Seeker of Souls
entries: At 17th level, you gain the ability to seek out spirits on the Ethereal Plane, and help to send them on their way.
{@b Ethereal Vision}: You can see 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when you are on the material plane and vice versa.

{@b Ethereal Walker}: You can enter the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa. You are visible on the Material Plane while you are in the Border Ethereal, and vice versa, yet you can't affect or be affected by anything on the other plane.
